DOC.HEAD: Japan-Soviet Peace Treaty Talks Stall Over Land Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Japanese and Soviet negotiators trying to draft a treaty to formally end their World War II hostilities wound up talks today with ``absolutely no new points of contact,'' a Foreign Ministry official said. Although both governments have expressed a desire to improve their chilly relations, the Japanese official said neither was willing to compromise on a territorial dispute over several islands in the southern Kurile chain held by the Soviets since the end of the war in 1945. ``There were absolutely no new points of contact,'' said the official, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity. He said the Soviet delegation called Soviet possession of the islands a ``postwar reality,'' and urged Japan to ``assume a stance that recognizes the results of the war.'' Japan, however, renewed its claim to what it calls the ``northern territories,'' a group of small islands off Hokkaido, Japan's northernmost main island. The official said the Soviet delegation proposed the exchange of draft treaties, but that Japan refused because of ``reservations regarding the validity of such drafts'' while the territorial dispute continues. Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Igor Rogachev, head of the Soviet delegation, was scheduled to continue talks with his Japanese counterpart, Hisashi Owada, on a less formal level Tuesday, the official said. Rogachev, completing a tour of five Asian nations, is scheduled to fly back to Moscow Wednesday. The apparent failure of the talks comes less than two weeks after Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, prompted by rapid changes in Eastern Europe and the recent mood of East-West detente, called for a new era in bilateral relations. Exchanges between the two nations have recently increased, and along with a scheduled visit of Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze next March, Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev is expected to visit Japan in 1991. If he does, he will be the first Soviet president to do so. Foreign Ministry officials said their expectations for any new developments were low going into the talks, but room for compromise had been indicated earlier by Politburo member Alexander Yakovlev, a close adviser to Gorbachev who during a visit to Tokyo last month spoke of a possibility of a ``third route'' toward improved relations. However, no progress toward opening up a new path was made in today's talks, the official said, adding that both countries continue to have a ``different approach.'' ``What the Japanese call the territorial problem, we call the definition of borders,'' he quoted a Soviet official as saying. He said most of the seven-hour talks dealt with the Soviet claim to historical and legal jurisdiction over the islands, which they say have belonged to Russia since the late 18th century and were defined as Soviet territory by the Yalta Conference in 1945 and the San Francisco Peace Treaty of 1951. Japan disputes those claims, countering that the islands have been an integral part of its territory since ancient times. Tokyo also claims a treaty signed in 1855 and a treaty ending the Russo-Japanese War in 1905 give Japan rightful ownership.
